text: 1. Anaesthetic agents: Ketamine IV bolus 0.5-1mg/kg over 2-4min, then infusion 0.5-2mg/kg/hour, inhaled halothane, isoflurane, enflurane, sevoflurane 2. Parenteral beta-agonists: suspected anaphylactic reaction or unable to use inhaled bronchodilators, adrenalin 0.3 to 0.5 mg IM/SC (1:1000 solution) 3. Helium-oxygen (heliox) via nebulizer or in ventilated patients 4. Leukotriene receptor antagonists (montelukast 10mg daily) in patients whose exacerbation was triggered by ingestion of aspirin or NSAID 5. Intravenous methylxanthines (theophylline, aminophylline) not recommended, but can continue chronic oral therapy 6. Antibiotics if suspected bacterial sinusitis or pneumonia complicating an asthmatic attack (cover atypical organisms) Indications for immediate intubation 1. Urgent clinical decision 2. Slowing of the respiratory rate 3. Depressed mental status, confusion 4. Inability to maintain respiratory effort and cough 5. Worsening hypercapnia and associated respiratory acidosis 6. Worsening hypoxia or inability to maintain an oxygen saturation >90% 7. Haemodynamic instability 8. Associated pneumonia or severe sepsis Non-invasive ventilation 1. Trial of NIV if no indications for immediate intubation 2. RR>30, PEFR <50%, hemodynamically stable, fully conscious and co-operative 3. Close monitoring of HR, RR, saturations, ABG, LOC 4.
